repnme.cdata!:
Eritrea - Health Project, and HIV/AIDS,
            Malaria, STD and Tuberculosis Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health Project for
            Eritrea are as follows: outcome was moderately
            unsatisfactory; risk to the development outcome was
            moderate; Bank performance was moderately satisfactory; and
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory.
            Ratings for the HIV/AIDS, Malaria, STD and Tuberculosis
            Control Project for Eritrea are as follows: outcome was
            moderately satisfactory; risk to the development outcome was
            moderate; Bank performance was satisfactory; and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            projects included: in post-conflict settings engagement is a
            means to an end and needs to be accompanied by a sustained
            policy dialogue to ensure that development gains are
            realized in the medium term. In the area of HIV/AIDS a
            demand-driven model of community sub-projects is more
            appropriate for service delivery interventions that are
            responsive to local community needs (such as home-based
            care, support to orphans and vulnerable children) than for
            preventive interventions targeting stigmatized risk groups
            or stigmatized behavior. Community activities that are
            strategically planned and coordinated with the local health
            authorities can provide an important complement to health
            facility-based disease control efforts. Disease control
            projects can be complementary to and need not undermine
            cross-cutting health system functions. Multi-sector
            projects, such as HIV/AIDS projects, achieve better results
            if the sectors involved are strategically chosen according
            to their comparative advantage in disease prevention and control.

repnme.cdata!:
Eritrea - HIV/AIDS, Malaria, STD and
            Tuberculosis (HAMSET) Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the HIV/AIDS, Malaria,
            STD and Tuberculosis (HAMSET) Control Project of Eritrea
            were as follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory and the Borrower performance was highly
            satisfactory. The lessons learned included the following:
            (1) HAMSET provides several important lessons regarding the
            Bank's Multi-Country AIDS Program (MAP) projects. The
            lessons are particularly important since HAMSET is one of
            the first MAP projects that has closed and been immediately
            followed by a second one. In addition, HAMSET design, with
            its multi-disease approach, was different from most MAP
            projects which focus only on HIV/AIDS. The lessons, varying
            from stewardship of MAP projects to their sustainability,
            have relevance beyond Eritrea to other countries. The
            lessons learned included the following: (1) Project design
            should be flexible and tailored for the country; (2)
            Mobilizing communities and relevant sectors are keys; (3)
            Effectively integrate activities of vertical disease
            programs, reproductive health and support health systems;
            (4) Clarify policy on the use of DDT as the environmental
            aspect of Malaria control has been complicated by the mixed
            messages over the use of DDT among international
            organizations and governments; (5) Build local capacity for
            planning and budgeting; (6) Procurement can be facilitated
            by innovative thinking; (7) Give monitoring and evaluation
            higher priority in design and prepare early for collection
            of data for analysis of cost effectiveness; (8) Address the
            discordance between knowledge, attitude and practice on
            HAMSET diseases; (9) Address the challenges of
            sustainability, starting with integration and community
            ownership; (10) Address the shortage of human resources for
            health; and (11) The report-based disbursement system (which
            was adopted in the second half of the project) allowed more
            predictable cash flow, more flexibility and facilitated
            project implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Eritrea - HIV/AIDS, Malaria, STDS and TB
            (HAMSET) Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The HIV/AIDS, Malaria, STDS and TB
            (HAMSET) Control Project, will help reduce mortality, and
            morbidity rates among the Eritrean population, applying
            quality health services in the prevention, diagnosis, and
            treatment of such diseases, through supportive health
            practices. The components call for: 1) data collection, and
            analysis to form the basis for planning, and responding to
            changes in disease trends, and epidemics. Component
            activities include surveillance techniques to improve
            HAMSET; establishment of an epidemic forecasting, and
            preparedness system; capacity building to improve
            operational research in the identification of HAMSET
            changes; methodology to link research, and
            monitoring/evaluation results, to policy formulation; and,
            disease management training at the Ministry of Health; 2)
            multi-sectoral control of HAMSET transmission, through
            increased information, capacity building, and education
            practices on healthy behaviors, access to preventive and
            diagnostic services, and environmental techniques for
            malaria vector control; 3) strengthening diagnostic, health
            care, and counseling services, by establishing blood banks,
            and improving prevention management, laboratory diagnosis,
            and availability of drugs; 4) identification of mechanisms
            to minimize transmission, through community counseling, and
            management responsiveness; and, 5) project management,
            emphasizing on monitoring and evaluation.

692876.trustfund:
TF028941-HIV/AIDS/MALARIA/SEXUALLY
            TRANSMITTED DISEASES/TUBERCULOSIS CONTROBL PR,TF040120-ERITREA: HIV/AIDS,TF039359-ERITREA - HEALTH RESTRUCTURING PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Eritrea - Malaria/HIV/AIDS STDS and TB
            (HAMSET) Control Project : Environmental evaluation

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental evaluation reviews
            those components of the malaria control program in Eritrea,
            that might possibly have adverse environmental side-effects,
            unless properly planned, and managed. The continued use of
            the insecticide DDT is a major concern, and this evaluation
            finds that, consistent with the World Health
            Organization's guidelines, its use is effective, when
            used in high risk areas to prevent epidemic conditions.
            However, plans to phase out DDT should be developed, and
            alternate replacement insecticides tested. Recommendations,
            and mitigating measures include: 1) annual testing - for a
            period of five years - of the susceptibility of vectors in
            the field of DDT. In addition, pyrethroids, and other
            formulations, should be tested to select the most suitable,
            based on efficacy, safety, and economic value, and be
            pilot-tested against DDT during the third to fifth year,
            when DDT should begin phasing-out; 2) capacity building, and
            strengthening the infrastructure of the National Malaria
            Control Program, focusing on entomology training, and
            collection of baseline biological data, to support
            monitoring of vector control components; 3) develop a
            strategy for community-based implementation, and maintenance
            of insecticide impregnated bed nets; and, 4) improve the
            collection, and analysis of data leading to
            cost-effectiveness information on different methods of
            malaria vector control.

display_title.display_title:
Eritrea - Malaria/HIV/AIDS STDS
            and TB (HAMSET) Control Project : Environmental evaluation
            (Vol. 2) : Environmental analysis and executive summary
